SENT.plain: Portal vein thrombosis, except in hepatocellular carcinoma and severe cirrhosis, is due to one or several prothrombotic disorders with or without a local precipitating factor
We report a case of a portal and splenic vein thrombosis, without cavernoma and varices which occurred in a 72-year-old man with abdominal pain and weakness
Three prothrombotic states including latent myeloproliferative disorder, antiphospholipid syndrome, and factor II G202101 mutation, were observed
Anticoagulant treatment resulted in complete repermeation of the portal and splenic veins without a hemorrhagic event
This illustrates that several prothrombotic states may occur in a single patient with portal vein thrombosis
Early anticoagulant therapy, in recent portal vein thrombosis, can result in repermeation
